Powell The superiority of this new
market was quite astounding
to my companions and
281 they began to abuse the
traders by whom they had
^ while in their
in their ownown country
country been visited and as they
now declared "cheated" They
haved no idea of the value
of time and carriage and it was somewhat
difficult for me to convince
them that the reason of
the difference wasof prices
lay entirely in what they
themselves had done in coming
here, and that if the Portuguese
should carry goods to their
country they would by
no means be so liberal in
their prices - They imagined
that if the Cassange, traders
Linyanti came to Linyanti they
would continue to vend at
vend their
goods at Cassange prices - I believe
I gave them at last a
clear idea of the manner
in which prices were
regulated by the expenses
incurred and thwhen we
went to LoandaLuanda and saw
2 45
goods delivered at a still cheaper
rate they concluded that
it would be better for them to
come to that city than go to
to turn ^ homewards at Cassange -

It was interesting for me
to observe the effects of the
restrictive policy pursued
by the Cape Government
towards the Bechuanas -
Like all other restrictions
on trade, that ^ the law of preventing
friendly tribes from purchasing
arms and ammunition
only injures the men who
make them enforce it - The
Cape Government as already
observed in order to
gratify a company of independantindependent
Boers whose well known
predilictionpredilection for the practice
of slavery caused them to desire
stipulate ^ that a number of peaceable
honest tribes ^ should be kept defenceless,
agreed to allow free trade in
arms and ammunition
to the Boers, and prevent the
same ^ trade to the Bechuanas - The
Cape Government thereby
unintentionally aided the Boers
to enslave the natives - But
arms and ammunition
flow in on all sides by
new channels, and where
formerly the price of ^ onea large
3 46
tusk procured but one musket
oneand one a such tusk of the same
size brings ten guns - The
profits are reaped by other
nations and the only
persons really the losers
in the long run are our
own Cape merchants and
a few defenceless tribes
of beBechuanas on our
immediate frontier -

Mr Reego the Commandant
very handsomely offered me a
guard of a soldier to Ambaca
My men told me that they
had been thinking it would
be better to turn back here
as they had been informed
by the people of colour at
Cassange that I was taking
leading ^ them down to the sea coast
only ^ to sell them and they
would be taken on board
ship and fattened and eaten
as the white men were
cannibals - I asked if they
had ever heard of an Englishman
buying or selling people - If
I had not refused to take
a slave when she was offered
to me by Shinte - but as
I had always behaved as an
English teacher if they now doubted
my intentions they had
4 47
better not go to the coast - I however
who expected to meet some
of my countrymen there was
determined to go on They
replied that they only thought
it right to tell me what
had been told them but
they did not intend to leave
me - and would follow where-
ever I wentto should lead
the way - This affair being
disposed of for the time
the Commandant gave
them an ox and having
gave invited me to as a friendly
dinner before parting
All the merchants of
Cassange accompanied
us in their hammocks
carried by slaves to the
edge of the plateau on
which their village stands
and Iwe parted I feeling that
I should never forget
their disinterested kindness
They not only did every-
thing they could to make
my men & me comfortable during my
stay but there being no
Hotelshotels in LoandaLuanda they
gave me letters of recommendation
to their friends in that city
to recievereceive me into their
houses - for without these
a stranger might find himself a
5 48
lodger in the streets - May God
remember them in their day of
need -

The Latitude and Longitude
of Cassange the most Easterly
station of the Portuguese
in Western Africa is Lat -Latitude 9° 37'
South - and Long -Longitude 17° 43'
Powell East - consequently we had
still about 300 miles
282 -------- to traverse before we could
reach the coast - We had
a soldier a black
Militia
corporal as a guide - A He was a
native of Ambaca who and
as ^ like nearly all the inhabitants
of that district passing
known by the name Ambacistas
could both read and write,
He had three slaves with
him and was carried by
them in ^ a "Tipoia" or hammock
slung to a pole - His slaves
were young and unable
to convey him far at a time
but he was considerate
enough to walk always
except when we came
near a village - He
then mounted his tipoia
and entered the village in
state his departure was
made in the same manner
and he continued in it till
the village was out of sight
6 49
It was interesting to observe
the manners of our soldier
guide - Two slaves were
always employed in carrying
his tipoia & the ^ third carried a
wooden box about three
feet long containing his
writing materials and
dishes and clothing - He
was cleanly in all his ways
but quite black ^ and when he scolded any
one of his own black
colour abused him as a
"negro" - When he wanted
to purchase any article
from a village he would
sit down, mix a little
gun powder as ink and
write a note ^ for it in a neat
hand to ask the price and addressed it to
the shop keeper by with the rather
pompous title "Illustrissimo
Senhor" - Most Illustrious Sir -
This is the invariable style
mode ^ of address throughout
Angola - The answer
returned would be in the
same style and if satisfactory
another note followed,
There is so much of this
note correspondence
carried on in Angola that
a very large quantity of note
paper is annually consumed
7 50
Some other peculiarities of our
guide were not so pleasing
A land of slaves is a bad
school for even the free -
and we were sorry to find
less truthfulness and honesty
in him than in my own
people - We were often cheated
through his connivance
with the sellers of food
and could percieveperceive that
he got a share of the
plunder from them - The
food is very cheap but
it was generally made dear
enough untilluntil I refused
to allow him to come
near the place where
we were bargaining - But
he took us safely down
to Ambaca and I was
glad to see on my return
to Cassange that hise
was promoted to be
sergeant major of a
company of militia

Having left Cassange
on the 21st we passed
across the remaining portion
of this excessively fertile
valley to the foot of Tala
MungongaMungongo - We crossed a
fine little stream called the
Lui on the 22 - and another
8 51
named the Luare on the 24th
then slept at the bottom
of the ^ heightascent which
is about from a thousand
a thousand to fifteen hundred
feet - The clouds came
floating along the valley
and broke against the
sides of the ascent and
the dripping rain on the
tall grass made the slaps
in the face ^ it gave when the
hand ^ or a stick was not held
up ^ before it anything but agreeable
This edge of the valley is
exactly like the other
jutting spurs and defiles
give the red ascent the
same ^ serrated appearance as that
we descended beffrom the
highlands of Londa - The
whole of this vast valley
has been removed by
denudation for pieces of
plateau which once
filled the now cevacant
space stand in it and
present the same structure
of red horizontal strata
of the same altitudes
as that we are now
about to ascend - One
of these named Kasala
bore E - S - E -East South East from the
place where we made our
9 52
exit from the valley - and
about ten miles W - S - W -West South West from
the village of Cassange It
is remarkable as having
such perpendicular sides
that even the natives
find it extremely difficult
almost impossible to obtain ^ reach it access to its
summit ^ top though there is the temptation
of Marabou nests and
the feathers which are
highly prized - There is
a small Lake reported
to exist on its Southern
end, and during the
rainy season a sort of
natural moat is formed
around the bottom - What
an acquisition this would
have been in feudal
times in England - Land
sufficient for considerable
cultivation on the top
with almost perpendicular
sides more than a thousand
feet in height -

div.p:
We had not yet got
a clear idea of the nature
of Tala MungongaMungongo - a gentleman
at Cassange described it as
a range of very high
mountains which ^ it would
10 53
occupy ^ take four hours in the to climb ^ ascent -
so though the rain and grass
had wet us miserably we
and I was suffering from
an attack of fever got
while observing by night
for position of
Cassange I eagerly commenced
the ascent - The path was
steep and slippery and
Ddeep gorges appear on each
side of it leaving but
a narrow path along certain
sierra spurs of the sierra for
the traveller but we
accomplished the ascent
in an hour - and when
there found we had just
got on to a table land
similar to that we had
left before we entered
the great Quango valley
We had come ^ and among lofty trees
again one of these
bearing a fruit about
the size of a thirtytwothirty-two pounder
is named Mononga zambi,
We took a glance back to
this most fertile valley which
equals that
of the MississipiMississippi
in fertility
and thought of the prodigious
massesvast mass of material
which had been scooped
out and carried away
in its formation - That
11 54
This naturally led to ^ reflection on the countless
ages required for the
previous formation and deposition
of thsesthe same material (clay slate)
Then of the rocks whose grinding
abrasion ^ down formed that untill
the mind groews giddy in
asttempting to ascend the
steps which lead up through
a portion of the Eternity
before man - The different
epochs of geology are
like ^ its landmarks in that
otherwise
shoreless
sea , inOur own
epoch isor creation is but
another added to the number
of that wonderful series
which presents a grand
display of the mighty power
of God - So far from
this science having any
tendency to make men
undervalue the power or
love of God it leads to
the ^ probability idea that the display of
mercy we have in ththe
gift of his son may
possibly not be the only
manifestation of grace &
love ^ which has taken place
in the countless ages
in which works of creation
have been going on,

12 55
Situated a few miles from
the edge of the descent we
found the village of
Tala MungongaTala Mungongo and were
kindly accommodated inwith
a house to sleep in
which ^ was very welcome
foras ^ we were all both
wet and cold - We found
that the greater altitude &
the approach
of winter lowered the temperature
so much that we many
of my men suffered
severely from colds - At
this as at several other
Portuguese stations they
have been proovvident
enough f to erect travellerstravellers'
houses on the same principle
as Khans or Caravanserai’s
of the East- They are ofbuilt
of the usual wattle
and daub and have
benches of rods for the
wayfarer to make his
bed on - Also chairs &
a table and a large jar
of water -These wbenches
though far from luxurious
couches were better than
the ground under my the rotten fragments of amy
gypseygypsy ^ tent for we had still
showers occasionally and
the dews were very heavy
I continued to use them
13 56
for the sake of the shelter they
afforded untilluntil I found
that they were lodgings for
certain inconvenient bed-
-fellows

Powell 27th Five hourshours' ride through
a pleasant well country
of forest and meadow like
Londa ^ brought us to a village of Basongo
a tribe living in subjection
to the Portuguese - We crossed
several little streams
which were flowing
in the Westerly direction
in which we were marching
to fand unite to form
Quize the Quize a feeder of the
Coanza Coanza - The Basongo
were very civil as
indeed all the tribes
awere who haved been
conquered by the Portuguese,
The Basongo and Bangala
are ^ yet only partially subdued
The farther west we go
go from this we
find the black population
less independantindependent untilluntil
we reach the confines
vicinity of LoandaLuanda where
the free natives ^ they are nearly identical
in their feelings towards the Government with the slaves
14 57
But the Govern^orsment of
Angola wisely accepts the
limited allegiance and
tribute rendered by the
more distant tribes as better
than none -

All the inhabitants of
this region as well as
those of Londa may be
called true negroes if the
limitations formerly made
be borne in mind - The
dark colour, thick lips ^ flat, heads
elongated backwards and
upwards and covered with
wool flat noses and with other negro
peculiarities are general
but while these characteristics
place them in the true negro
family, the reader would
imbibe a wrong idea did
if he supposed that all
these features ^ combined are often met
with in one individual
Thus All arehave
a certain
thickness
& prominence
of lips but, , many are met with
in every village in whom
thickness and projection
of lips is nare not more
marked than in some
Europeans - All are dark
but that colour is shaded
off in different individuals
from deep black to light
yellow - As we go Westwards
15 58
we observe the light colour
predominating over the dark
and then again when we
come within the influence
of damp from the sea
air, we find the shade
deepen again into the
general blackness of
the coast population,
The shape of the head with
its wooly crop though
general is not universal
The Caffre head The tribes
on the Eastern side of the
continent as the Caffres
have heads finely
developed and strongly
European - Instances of
this kind are so numerous
frequently seen and I have
after I became so
familiar with the dark
colour as to forget it
in viewing the countenance
I have been struck by
the strong resemblances
some personsnatives bore
to certain of our own
notabilities - The Bushmen
and Hottentots are exceptions
to these remarks for both
the shape of their heads
and growth of wool
are peculiar - The latter
16 59
for instance frsprings from
the scalp in tufts with
bare spaces between and
when the crop is short
resembles a number of
black peppercorns stuck on the
skin - head, and very unlike
the thick frizzly masses
ofwhich cover the heads
of the Balonda and Maravi
With every disposition
to pay due deference to
the opinions of those
who have made Ethnology
their special study I
have felt myself unable
to believe that the
exaggerated features usually
put forth as those of
the typical negro characterize
any nation of south
central Africa - The
monuments of ^ the Ancient
Egyptians seem to me
to embody the ideal
of the inhabitants of
Londa better than the
figures of any work
of Ethnology I have met
with -

17 60
Sunday 30th We spent at Ngio
(pronounced Njeeo)

Passing through ^ the same fine
fertile and well peopled
Sanza country to Sanza we found
the Quize again touching
our path and here
we had the pleasure of
seeing a field of wheat
growing luxuriantly without
irrigation - The ears were
upwards of ^ four inches long and
were an object of great
curiosity to my companions
because they had tasted
my bread at Linyanti
but had never before
seen wheat growing.
This small field was
cultivated by Mr Miland
an agreableagreeable Portuguese
gmerchant - His garden
was interesting as shewingshowing
what the land at this
elevation is capable of
abyielding for besides
wheat he had we
saw European vegetables
in a flourishing condition
and we afterwards discovered
that the coffee plant has
propagated itself oneon certain
spots parts of this same district
And It may be seen
18 61
on the heights of Tala MungongaTala Mungongo
or nearly 300 miles from
the West coast where it was
first introduced by the
Jesuit missionaries -

We spent Sunday 30th
April at Ngio (soft g) Njeeo)
close to the ford of the Quize
The country becomes more
open ^ but is still abundantly
fertile with a
thick crop
of grass
about
between two
and three
feet high
It is also and well wooded
and watered - Villages of
Basongo are dotted over
the country ^ landscape and frequently
a square houses of
wattle and daub belonging
to a native Portuguese
are placed beside them
for the purpose of trade
The people here possess
both cattle and pigs - The
different sleeping places
on our path arefrom
eight to ten miles apart
are marked by a cluster
of sheds made of sticks
and grass - There is
a constant stream
of people going and
returning to & from
the coast - The goods are
carried on the head or
on one shoulder in a
sort of basket having
planted between attached to at the extremities of two poles
19 61a
stet between five to and six feet ^ in length long
& called Motete - When the basket is placed on
the head, the poles project
forwards horizontally and
when the carrier wishes
to rest himself he places
th plants them on the ground
& the burden against a tree
so he is they are not obliged to lift
it up from the ground to the
level of the head - It stands
against the tree propped up
by the poles at that level -
The carrier They frequently plants the
poles on the ground &
stands holding the burden
untilluntil they have ^ he has taken
breath thus avoiding the
trouble of placing the
burden on the ground &
lifting it up again

When a company of these
carriers or our own
party ^ company comes to one
of these sleeping places
immediate possession
is taken of the sheds
Those who come late
and find all the hoccupied
must then erect others
for themselves - but
this is not difficult
for there is no lack
of long grass - No sooner
20 62
do the ^ any strangers appear at the
spot than the women may
be seen emerging from
their villages bearing
baskets of manioc meal
roots ^ earth-nuts, yams - birdsbird's eye
pepper and garlic for sale,
Calico of which we had
brought some from
Cassange is the chief
medium of exchange
We found them all civil
& though it was evident
from the amount of
talking and laughing in
bargaining that the ladies
enjoyed their occupation
They must cultivate
largely in order to be
able to supply the constant
succession of strangers
Those ^ however near to the great
line of road purchase
also ^ much of the food
also from the more
distant villages for the
sake of gain -

Pitsane and another of
the men had violent attacks
ofor fever, and it was no
wonder for the dampfness
& evaporation from of the ground was excessive
When at any time I attempted
to get an observation
of a star, if the trough
